Section.Description: Structure depictions and information for 2D, 3D, and crystal related
Record identifiers, synonyms, chemical names, descriptors, etc.
Descriptors generated from chemical structure input
Chemical name computed from chemical structure that uses International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature standards.

Reference: Computed by LexiChem 2.6.6 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: International Chemical Identifier (InChI) computed from chemical structure using the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) standard.

Reference: Computed by InChI 1.0.5 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: International Chemical Identifier hash (InChIKey) computed from chemical structure using the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) standard.

Reference: Computed by InChI 1.0.5 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: Simplified Molecular-Input Line-Entry System (SMILES) computed from chemical structure devoid of isotopic and stereochemical information.

Reference: Computed by OEChem 2.1.5 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: Important identifiers assigned to this chemical substance by authoritative organizations
A proprietary registry number assigned by the Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) division of the American Chemical Society (ACS) often used to help describe chemical ingredients.

A seven-digit regulatory identifier currently assigned by the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) known as a European Community (EC) number.  It is sometimes referred to as an EINECS, ELINCS, or NLP number, which are subsets of an EC number.

A four-digit number assigned by the United Nations Committee of Experts on the Transport of Dangerous Goods used to identify hazardous materials (hazmat) internationally. To learn information to each UN number, visit the Emergency Response Guidebook.
Substance identifier at the Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) Database.
Links to Wikipedia or wikidata for this record.
Shipping Name/ Number DOT/UN/NA/IMO
Standard Transportation Number

Alternative names for this PubChem Compound record.  A compound can have many different names.  For example, acetone (CH3C(=O)CH3) is also known as propanone, propan-2-one, or dimethyl ketone.  The brand name of a product is commonly used to indicate the primary chemical ingredient(s) in the product (e.g., Tylenol, a common pain killer, is often used for acetaminophen, its active ingredient).  Another example of common synonyms is record identifiers used in different data collections, such as Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) registry numbers, FDA UNII (Unique Ingredient Identifiers), and many others.  All these various names and identifiers that designate this compound are organized under the Synonyms section.

Chemical names provided by individual data contributors. Synonyms of Substances corresponding to a PubChem Compound record are combined. Some contributed names may be considered erroneous and filtered out. The link on each synonym shows which depositors provided that particular synonym for this structure.
Chemical and physical properties such as melting point, molecular weight, etc.
Properties computed automatically from the given chemical structure

Molecular weight or molecular mass refers to the mass of a molecule. It is calculated as the sum of the mass of each constituent atom multiplied by the number of atoms of that element in the molecular formula.

Reference: Computed by PubChem 2.1 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: Hydrogen Bond Donor count

Reference: Computed by Cactvs 3.4.6.11 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: Hydrogen Bond Acceptor count

Reference: Computed by Cactvs 3.4.6.11 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: Rotatable bond is defined as any single non-ring bond, bounded to nonterminal heavy (i.e., non-hydrogen) atom.

Reference: Computed by Cactvs 3.4.6.11 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: The exact mass of an isotopic species is obtained by summing the masses of the individual isotopes of the molecule.

Reference: Computed by PubChem 2.1 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: The monoisotopic mass is the sum of the masses of the atoms in a molecule using the unbound, ground-state, rest mass of the principal (most abundant) isotope for each element instead of the isotopic average mass.

Reference: Computed by PubChem 2.1 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: The topological polar surface area (TPSA) of a molecule is defined as the surface sum over all polar atoms in a molecule.

Reference: Computed by Cactvs 3.4.6.11 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: A heavy atom is defined as any atom except hydrogen in a chemical structure.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: Formal charge is the difference between the number of valence electrons of each atom and the number of electrons the atom is associated with. Formal charge assumes any shared electrons are equally shared between the two bonded atoms.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: The complexity rating of a compound is a rough estimate of how complicated a structure is, seen from both the point of view of the elements contained and the displayed structural features including symmetry. This complexity rating is computed using the Bertz/Hendrickson/Ihlenfeldt formula.

Reference: Computed by Cactvs 3.4.6.11 (PubChem release 2019.06.18)

Section.Description: Isotopte Atom Count is the number of isotopes that are not most abundant for the corresponding chemical elements.  Isotopes are variants of a chemical element which differ in neutron number.  For example, among three isotopes of carbon (i.e., C-12, C-13, and C-14), the isotope atom count considers the C-13 and C-14 atoms, because C-12 is the most abundant isotope of carbon.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: An atom stereocenter, also known as a chiral center, is an atom that is attached to four different types of atoms (or groups of atoms) in the tetrahedral arrangement. It can have either (R)- or (S)- configurations.  Some compounds, such as racemic mixtures, have an undefined atom stereocenter, whose (R/S)-configuration is not specifically defined.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: An atom stereocenter, also known as a chiral center, is an atom that is attached to four different types of atoms (or groups of atoms) in the tetrahedral arrangement. It can have either (R)- or (S)- configurations.  Some compounds, such as racemic mixtures, have an undefined atom stereocenter, whose (R/S)-configuration is not specifically defined.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: A bond stereocenter is a non-rotatable bond around which two atoms can have different arrangement (as in cis- and trans-forms of butene around its double bond).  Some compounds have an undefined bond stereocenter, whose stereochemistry is not specifically defined.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: A bond stereocenter is a non-rotatable bond around which two atoms can have different arrangement (as in cis- and trans-forms of butene around its double bond).  Some compounds have an undefined bond stereocenter, whose stereochemistry is not specifically defined.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: Covalently-Bonded Unit Count

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: Compound is canonicalized

Reference: Computed by PubChem (release 2019.01.04)

Section.Description: Properties determined experimentally (See also Safety and Hazard Properties section for more information if available)
Physical description refers to the appearance or features of a given chemical compound including color, odor, state, taste and more in general

StringWithMarkup.String: Vanadium tetrachloride appears as a red liquid with a pungent odor. Boiling point 309.2°F (154°C). Corrosive to metals and tissue.

Section.Description: Physical description - color

Reference: Ashford, R.D. Ashford's Dictionary of Industrial Chemicals. London, England: Wavelength Publications Ltd., 1994., p. 937
Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 4-98

Section.Description: Physical description - odor

Reference: Rydzynski K, Pakulska D; Vanadium, Niobium, and Tantalum. Patty's Toxicology. 6th ed. (1999-2016). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons, Inc. On-line Posting Date: 27 Jan 2012.

StringWithMarkup.String: Pungent odor due to slow decomposition at room temperature with Cl2 formation

Section.Description: The boiling point of a substance is the temperature at which the vapor pressure of the liquid equals the pressure surrounding the liquid and the liquid changes into a vapor

Reference: Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 4-98

Section.Description: The melting point is the temperature at which a substance changes state from solid to liquid at atmospheric pressure. When considered as the temperature of the reverse change, from liquid to solid, it is referred to as the freezing point.

Reference: Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 4-98

Section.Description: The solubility of a substance is the amount of that substance that will dissolve in a given amount of solvent. The default solvent is water, if not indicated.

Reference: Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 4-98
Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 4-98

StringWithMarkup.String: Soluble in ethanol and ethyl ether

Section.Description: The density of a substance is its mass per unit volume.

Reference: Larranaga, M.D., Lewis, R.J. Sr., Lewis, R.A.; Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary 16th  Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Hoboken, NJ 2016., p. 1411

Section.Description: Vapor density is the density of a vapor in relation to that of hydrogen

Reference: Dutch Assoc of Safety Experts; Handling Chemicals Safely 2nd ed p.952 (1980)

Section.Description: Vapor pressure is the pressure of a vapor in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed phases in a closed system.

Reference: Daubert TE, Danner RP; Physical and Thermodynamic Properties of Pure Chemicals: Data Compilation.  Design Institute for Physical Property Data, American Institute of Chemical Engineers. Hemisphere Pub Corp, New York, NY (1992)

Section.Description: Tendency of a material to resist change or decomposition due to internal reaction, or due to the action of air, heat, light, pressure, etc. (See also Stability and Reactivity section under Safety and Hazards)

Reference: Sigma-Aldrich; Safety Data Sheet for Vanadium(IV) chloride. Product Number: 366617, Version 4.9 (Revision Date 12/01/2015). Available from, as of April 5, 2016: http://www.sigmaaldrich.com/safety-center.html

Section.Description: The decomposition temperature of a substance is the temperature at which the substance chemically decomposes

Reference: Dutch Assoc of Safety Experts; Handling Chemicals Safely 2nd ed p.952 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: Decomposes by action of light to form chlorine gas.

Reference: Lewis, R.J. Sr.; Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary 15th  Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Inc. New York, NY 2007., p. 1312

StringWithMarkup.String: Decomposes slowly to vanadium trichloride and chlorine below 63 °C.

Reference: Lewis, R.J. Sr. (ed) Sax's Dangerous Properties of Industrial Materials. 11th Edition. Wiley-Interscience, Wiley & Sons, Inc. Hoboken, NJ. 2004., p. 3659

StringWithMarkup.String: When heated to decomposition it emits toxic fumes of /vanadium oxide/ and /chloride/.

Reference: National Fire Protection Association;  Fire Protection Guide to Hazardous Materials. 14TH Edition, Quincy, MA 2010, p. 49-153

StringWithMarkup.String: Not combustible, but if involved in a fire decomposes to produce hydrogen chloride and fumes of vanadium and vanadium oxides.

Section.Description: A measure of a corrosive substance that will destroy and damage other substances with which it comes into contact

Reference: NOAA; CAMEO Chemicals. Database of Hazardous Materials. Vanadium Tetrachloride (7632-51-1). Natl Ocean Atmos Admin, Off Resp Rest; NOAA Ocean Serv. Available from, as of April 8, 2016: http://cameochemicals.noaa.gov/

Section.Description: The Heat (or Enthalpy) of Vaporization is the quantity of heat that must be absorbed if a certain quantity of liquid is vaporized at a constant temperature.

Reference: Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 6-131

Section.Description: Additional property information.

Reference: Larranaga, M.D., Lewis, R.J. Sr., Lewis, R.A.; Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary 16th  Edition. John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Hoboken, NJ 2016., p. 1411

StringWithMarkup.String: Decomposes slowly to vanadium trichloride and chlorine below 63 °C

Reference: Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 6-151
Haynes, W.M. (ed.). CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics. 95th Edition. CRC Press LLC, Boca Raton: FL 2014-2015, p. 5-10

StringWithMarkup.String: Enthalpy of formation at 298.15 K: -569.4 kJ/mol (liquid); -525.5 kJ/mol (gas); molar heat capacity at 298.15 K: 96.2 J/mol K (gas)

Reference: Ashford, R.D. Ashford's Dictionary of Industrial Chemicals. London, England: Wavelength Publications Ltd., 1994., p. 937

NOAA; CAMEO Chemicals. Database of Hazardous Materials. Vanadium Tetrachloride (7632-51-1). Natl Ocean Atmos Admin, Off Resp Rest; NOAA Ocean Serv. Available from, as of April 8, 2016: http://cameochemicals.noaa.gov/

StringWithMarkup.String: Forms acid mists in moist air. Reacts with water to form corrosive fumes of HCl. Reacts violently or explosively with water.

Reference: Woolery M; Vanadium Compounds. Kirk-Othmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology. (1999-2016). New York, NY: John Wiley & Sons. Online Posting Date: 2 Dec 2005.

StringWithMarkup.String: Vanadium tetrachloride dissociates slowly at room temperature and rapidly at higher temperatures, yielding VCl3 and Cl2.
